metadata.subject: Portfolios, US corporate profits and the Twilight of the Gods (in the US, Europe, China and the IEA)

organizations: U.S. House Committee on Oversight and Accountability

relationships.description: Michael Cembalest is the Chief Investment Officer at J.P. Morgan Private Bank.
The bank manages assets and provides recommendations to clients.
The US government is dealing with federal debt ceiling issues and unfunded entitlements.
The EU and IMF are providing funds to Greece to prevent sovereign default.

analysis.purpose: To provide a market commentary on current economic conditions, portfolio allocations, and geopolitical risks.
analysis.significance: Highlights economic vulnerabilities in the US, Europe, and China, and discusses the limitations of government interventions.

notable_quotes: We are getting closer to the Twilight of the Gods, a time when they are either running out of ammunition, or the ability to use it without causing even more problems.
US labor compensation is now at a 50-year low relative to both company sales and US GDP.
I believe that eventually, the constituency of the European Monetary Union will have to change.
red_flags: elevated debt burdens in Italy and Greece
potential for sovereign default in Europe
negative real deposit rates in China

blackmail_indicators.description: No indicators of blackmail or coercion found; the document is an economic analysis.

illegal_activity.description: No illegal activity is discussed; the document is a legitimate market commentary.

public_knowledge.context: The document discusses widely reported economic issues such as the US debt ceiling, European sovereign debt crisis, and Chinese inflation, which were covered by media in 2011.

analysis.summary: This J.P. Morgan market commentary analyzes current portfolio allocations, highlighting high corporate profits driven by low labor costs, and discusses economic challenges in the US, Europe, and China, referring to these interventions as the 'Twilight of the Gods' due to their diminishing effectiveness.
